title: Warburg-Backed Princeton Enters Korea With First Data Center
description: Princeton Digital Group, a data center operator in Asia backed by Warburg Pincus, plans to invest $700 million in its first South Korean campus to power artificial intelligence development in the country.
content:

title: The AI revolution has begun - on personal phones and laptops
description: British businesses are pouring billions into artificial intelligence, yet it is staff who are spearheading AI adoption, often using personal devices

title: How will artificial intelligence change society? Ask a chatbot
description: How life changes even as we live it! – never more swiftly than now. Last year is old, next year unimaginable. We don’t know where we’re going and race on regardless. title: Rise of the robots: The promise of physical AI
description: A pair of swiveling, human-like robotic arms, built for physical artificial intelligence research, mirror the motions of an operator in a VR headset twirling his hands like a magician. With enough practice, arms like these can complete everyday tasks alone, says Tokyo company Enactic, which is developing humanoid robots to…

title: Peter Lynch on AI Stocks: 'I Literally Couldn't Pronounce Nvidia Until About Eight Months Ago'
description: Peter Lynch has stated that he does not hold any artificial intelligence (AI) stocks, despite the sector's recent surge.

title: Samsung plans $310 bil investment to power AI expansion

title: U.S. Google searches for AI bubble skyrockets 950%
description: U.S. concern over a potential artificial intelligence bubble is rising, with Google searches for “AI bubble” surging 950% year-over-year.
content:

title: Close To Half Indian Enterprises Use Generative AI, But Budget Still Sparse
description: Close to half of Indian enterprises are actively deploying artificial intelligence, with 47% of firms disclosing that they have had many use cases for generative AI, currently in production, according to a joint report by the Confederation of Indian Industry and Ernst & Young. Despite the increased adoption of AI, investment enthusiasm was still seen to be relatively muted, with over 95% of firms keeping AI and machine learning budgets below 20% of the overall IT spending
